sentences.sentence: So the little tailor( 裁缝 ) went on, always following his nose.
And after he had gone a long way, he entered the courtyard( 庭院 ) belonging to( 属于 ) a King’s palace, and there he felt so tired that he lay down and fell asleep.
In the meanwhile( 与此同时 ), various people came who looked at him very curiously( 好奇地 ), and read on his belt( 腰带 ), “Seven at one blow!”
“Oh!” said they. “Why should this great lord come here in time of peace? What a great fighter he must be.”
Then they went and told the King about him.
They thought that how useful such a man would be if there was a war, and decided that he ought not to be allowed to leave.
The King then called his council, and sent one of his men to the little tailor to ask him if he would agree to serve in the King’s army.
So the messenger( 通信员 ) stood and waited until the tailor woke up, and asked him.
“That was why I came,” said the little tailor. “I am ready to enter the King’s service.”
So he was given a good position in the army, and a house of his own.
But the rest of the soldiers( 士兵 ) were very jealous( 嫉妒的 ) of the little tailor, and they wished him a thousand miles away.
“What shall be done about it?” they said among themselves. “If we fight with him, then seven of us will die at each blow. That will be no good for us.”
So they made a decision, and went all together to the King to say that they wanted to leave the army.
“We never agreed,” they said, “to serve with a man who can kill seven at a blow.”
The King felt sorry to lose his whole army because of one man.
He wished that he had never seen the little tailor, and wanted to get rid( 摆脱 ) of him.
But he did not dare( 敢 ) to, because he was afraid that if he angered the tailor, the tailor would kill all the King’s soldiers and make himself King.
He thought a long while about it, and at last made up his mind what to do.
He sent for the little tailor, and told him that as the tailor was so great a fighter, he had a job for him.
He told him that in a wood nearby there were two giants( 巨人 ), who did great damage( 危害 ) by robbery( 抢劫 ), murder( 谋杀 ), and fire, and that no man dared to go near them for fear of his life.
But if the tailor killed both these giants, the King would give him his only daughter in marriage, and half his kingdom as a wedding( 婚礼 ) gift.
And the King also offered him a hundred horsemen( 骑手 ) to help him fight the giants.
“That would be something for a man like me!” thought the little tailor.
“It’s not every day you get a chance to marry a beautiful princess( 公主 ) and get half a kingdom!” and he said to the King,
“I can soon kill the giants. There will be no need for the hundred horsemen: someone who can kill seven at one blow has no need to be afraid of two.”
So the little tailor set out, and the horsemen followed him.
When he came to the wood he said to the horsemen,
“Stay here while I go and attack the giants.”
Then he went into the wood, and looked about him right and left.
After a while he caught sight of( 忽然看到 ) the two giants.
They were lying down under a tree asleep, and snoring( 打鼾 ) so that all the branches( 树枝 ) shook.
The little tailor filled his pockets with stones and climbed up into the tree.
He climbed out onto an overhanging( 挂着的 ) branch, just above the sleeping giants, and started to drop stones on one of them.
That giant woke up and pushed the other one, and said,
“What are you hitting me for?”
“You are dreaming,” said the other. “I’m not hitting you.”
And they went back to sleep.
Then the tailor dropped a stone on the other giant.
“What can that be?” cried he. “What are you throwing at me for?”
“I’m not throwing anything at you,” answered the first, grumbling( 抱怨 ).
They argued about it for a while, but as they were tired, they gave it up at last, and their eyes closed once more.
Then the little tailor started again. He chose a heavier stone, and threw it hard at the first giant.
“This is too much!” cried he, and jumped up like a madman( 疯子 ) and hit his companion( 同伴 ) so hard that the tree shook above them.
The other hit him back just as hard, and they fought with such fury( 暴怒 ) that they tore( 撕碎 ) up trees by their roots( 树根 ) to use for weapons( 武器 ) against each other.
At last both of them lay dead upon the ground. And now the little tailor got down.
“Another piece of luck!” said he.
“It’s a good thing that the tree I was sitting in did not get torn up too, or else I should have had to jump like a squirrel( 松鼠 ) from one tree to another.”

options.cn: 因为他们认为小裁缝可以一击七死。
